texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I talked a bit about systemd's network device name in my earlier post about  systemd-networkd and bonding  and I received some questions about how systemd rolls through the possible names of network devices to choose the final name. These predictable network device names  threw me a curveball last summer  when I couldn't figure out how the names were constructed.
texts.text: I talked a bit about systemd's network device name in my earlier post about  systemd-networkd and bonding  and I received some questions about how systemd rolls through the possible names of network devices to choose the final name. These predictable network device names  threw me a curveball last summer  when I couldn't figure out how the names were constructed.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Let's walk through this process.
texts.text: Let's walk through this process.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: What's in a name?
texts.text: What's in a name?

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Back in the systemd-networkd bonding post, I dug into a dual port Intel network card that showed up in a hotplug slot:
texts.text: Back in the systemd-networkd bonding post, I dug into a dual port Intel network card that showed up in a hotplug slot:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# udevadm info -e | grep -A 9 ^P.*eth0
P: /devices/pci0000:00/0000:00:03.2/0000:08:00.0/net/eth0
E: DEVPATH=/devices/pci0000:00/0000:00:03.2/0000:08:00.0/net/eth0
E: ID_BUS=pci
E: ID_MODEL_FROM_DATABASE=82599ES 10-Gigabit SFI/SFP+ Network Connection (Ethernet OCP Server Adapter X520-2)
E: ID_MODEL_ID=0x10fb
E: ID_NET_DRIVER=ixgbe
E: ID_NET_LINK_FILE=/usr/lib/systemd/network/99-default.link
E: ID_NET_NAME_MAC=enxa0369f2cec90
E: ID_NET_NAME_PATH=enp8s0f0
E: ID_NET_NAME_SLOT=ens9f0
texts.text:
# udevadm info -e | grep -A 9 ^P.*eth0
P: /devices/pci0000:00/0000:00:03.2/0000:08:00.0/net/eth0
E: DEVPATH=/devices/pci0000:00/0000:00:03.2/0000:08:00.0/net/eth0
E: ID_BUS=pci
E: ID_MODEL_FROM_DATABASE=82599ES 10-Gigabit SFI/SFP+ Network Connection (Ethernet OCP Server Adapter X520-2)
E: ID_MODEL_ID=0x10fb
E: ID_NET_DRIVER=ixgbe
E: ID_NET_LINK_FILE=/usr/lib/systemd/network/99-default.link
E: ID_NET_NAME_MAC=enxa0369f2cec90
E: ID_NET_NAME_PATH=enp8s0f0
E: ID_NET_NAME_SLOT=ens9f0

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This udev database dump shows that it came up with a few different names for the network interface:
texts.text: This udev database dump shows that it came up with a few different names for the network interface:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ID_NET_NAME_MAC=enxa0369f2cec90
texts.text: ID_NET_NAME_MAC=enxa0369f2cec90

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ID_NET_NAME_PATH=enp8s0f0
texts.text: ID_NET_NAME_PATH=enp8s0f0

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ID_NET_NAME_SLOT=ens9f0
texts.text: ID_NET_NAME_SLOT=ens9f0

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Where do these names come from? We can dig into systemd's source code to figure out the origin of the names and which one is selected as the final choice.
texts.text: Where do these names come from? We can dig into systemd's source code to figure out the origin of the names and which one is selected as the final choice.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Down the udev rabbit hole
texts.text: Down the udev rabbit hole

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Let's take a look at  src/udev/udev-builtin-net_id.c :
texts.text: Let's take a look at  src/udev/udev-builtin-net_id.c :

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
/*
 * Predictable network interface device names based on:
 *  - firmware/bios-provided index numbers for on-board devices
 *  - firmware-provided pci-express hotplug slot index number
 *  - physical/geographical location of the hardware
 *  - the interface's MAC address
 *
 * http://www.freedesktop.org/wiki/Software/systemd/PredictableNetworkInterfaceNames
 *
 * Two character prefixes based on the type of interface:
 *   en -- ethernet
 *   sl -- serial line IP (slip)
 *   wl -- wlan
 *   ww -- wwan
 *
 * Type of names:
 *   b<number>                             -- BCMA bus core number
 *   ccw<name>                             -- CCW bus group name
 *   o<index>[d<dev_port>]                 -- on-board device index number
 *   s<slot>[f<function>][d<dev_port>]     -- hotplug slot index number
 *   x<MAC>                                -- MAC address
 *   [P<domain>]p<bus>s<slot>[f<function>][d<dev_port>]
 *                                         -- PCI geographical location
 *   [P<domain>]p<bus>s<slot>[f<function>][u<port>][..][c<config>][i<interface>]
 *                                         -- USB port number chain
texts.text:
/*
 * Predictable network interface device names based on:
 *  - firmware/bios-provided index numbers for on-board devices
 *  - firmware-provided pci-express hotplug slot index number
 *  - physical/geographical location of the hardware
 *  - the interface's MAC address
 *
 * http://www.freedesktop.org/wiki/Software/systemd/PredictableNetworkInterfaceNames
 *
 * Two character prefixes based on the type of interface:
 *   en -- ethernet
 *   sl -- serial line IP (slip)
 *   wl -- wlan
 *   ww -- wwan
 *
 * Type of names:
 *   b<number>                             -- BCMA bus core number
 *   ccw<name>                             -- CCW bus group name
 *   o<index>[d<dev_port>]                 -- on-board device index number
 *   s<slot>[f<function>][d<dev_port>]     -- hotplug slot index number
 *   x<MAC>                                -- MAC address
 *   [P<domain>]p<bus>s<slot>[f<function>][d<dev_port>]
 *                                         -- PCI geographical location
 *   [P<domain>]p<bus>s<slot>[f<function>][u<port>][..][c<config>][i<interface>]
 *                                         -- USB port number chain

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: So here's where our names actually begin. Ethernet cards will always start with  en , but they might be followed by a  p  (for PCI slots), a  s  (for hotplug PCI-E slots), and  o  (for onboard cards). Scroll down just a bit more for some examples starting at line 56.
texts.text: So here's where our names actually begin. Ethernet cards will always start with  en , but they might be followed by a  p  (for PCI slots), a  s  (for hotplug PCI-E slots), and  o  (for onboard cards). Scroll down just a bit more for some examples starting at line 56.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Real-world examples
texts.text: Real-world examples

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: We already looked at the hotplug slot naming from Rackspace's OnMetal servers. They show up as  ens9f0  and  ens9f1 . That means they're on a hotplug slot which happens to be slot 9. The function indexes are 0 and 1 (for both ports on the Intel 82599ES).
texts.text: We already looked at the hotplug slot naming from Rackspace's OnMetal servers. They show up as  ens9f0  and  ens9f1 . That means they're on a hotplug slot which happens to be slot 9. The function indexes are 0 and 1 (for both ports on the Intel 82599ES).

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Linux firewall with a dual-port PCI card
texts.text: Linux firewall with a dual-port PCI card

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Here's an example of my Linux firewall at home. It's a Dell Optiplex 3020 with an Intel I350-T2 (dual port):
texts.text: Here's an example of my Linux firewall at home. It's a Dell Optiplex 3020 with an Intel I350-T2 (dual port):

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# udevadm info -e | grep -A 10 ^P.*enp1s0f1
P: /devices/pci0000:00/0000:00:01.0/0000:01:00.1/net/enp1s0f1
E: DEVPATH=/devices/pci0000:00/0000:00:01.0/0000:01:00.1/net/enp1s0f1
E: ID_BUS=pci
E: ID_MODEL_FROM_DATABASE=I350 Gigabit Network Connection (Ethernet Server Adapter I350-T2)
E: ID_MODEL_ID=0x1521
E: ID_NET_DRIVER=igb
E: ID_NET_LINK_FILE=/usr/lib/systemd/network/99-default.link
E: ID_NET_NAME=enp1s0f1
E: ID_NET_NAME_MAC=enxa0369f6e5227
E: ID_NET_NAME_PATH=enp1s0f1
E: ID_OUI_FROM_DATABASE=Intel Corporate
texts.text:
# udevadm info -e | grep -A 10 ^P.*enp1s0f1
P: /devices/pci0000:00/0000:00:01.0/0000:01:00.1/net/enp1s0f1
E: DEVPATH=/devices/pci0000:00/0000:00:01.0/0000:01:00.1/net/enp1s0f1
E: ID_BUS=pci
E: ID_MODEL_FROM_DATABASE=I350 Gigabit Network Connection (Ethernet Server Adapter I350-T2)
E: ID_MODEL_ID=0x1521
E: ID_NET_DRIVER=igb
E: ID_NET_LINK_FILE=/usr/lib/systemd/network/99-default.link
E: ID_NET_NAME=enp1s0f1
E: ID_NET_NAME_MAC=enxa0369f6e5227
E: ID_NET_NAME_PATH=enp1s0f1
E: ID_OUI_FROM_DATABASE=Intel Corporate

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: And the output from
texts.text: And the output from

texts.label: code
texts.orig: lspci
texts.text: lspci

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# lspci -s 01:00
01:00.0 Ethernet controller: Intel Corporation I350 Gigabit Network Connection (rev 01)
01:00.1 Ethernet controller: Intel Corporation I350 Gigabit Network Connection (rev 01)
texts.text:
# lspci -s 01:00
01:00.0 Ethernet controller: Intel Corporation I350 Gigabit Network Connection (rev 01)
01:00.1 Ethernet controller: Intel Corporation I350 Gigabit Network Connection (rev 01)

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This card happens to sit on PCI bus 1 (enp1), slot 0 (s0). Since it's a dual-port card, it has two function indexes (f0 and f1). That leaves me with two predictable names:  enp1s0f1  and  enp1s0f0 .
texts.text: This card happens to sit on PCI bus 1 (enp1), slot 0 (s0). Since it's a dual-port card, it has two function indexes (f0 and f1). That leaves me with two predictable names:  enp1s0f1  and  enp1s0f0 .

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: 1U server with four ethernet ports
texts.text: 1U server with four ethernet ports

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Let's grab another example. Here's a SuperMicro 1U X9SCA server with four onboard PCI ethernet cards:
texts.text: Let's grab another example. Here's a SuperMicro 1U X9SCA server with four onboard PCI ethernet cards:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# udevadm info -e | grep -A 10 ^P.*enp2s0
P: /devices/pci0000:00/0000:00:1c.4/0000:02:00.0/net/enp2s0
E: DEVPATH=/devices/pci0000:00/0000:00:1c.4/0000:02:00.0/net/enp2s0
E: ID_BUS=pci
E: ID_MODEL_FROM_DATABASE=82574L Gigabit Network Connection
E: ID_MODEL_ID=0x10d3
E: ID_NET_DRIVER=e1000e
E: ID_NET_LINK_FILE=/usr/lib/systemd/network/99-default.link
E: ID_NET_NAME=enp2s0
E: ID_NET_NAME_MAC=enx00259025963a
E: ID_NET_NAME_PATH=enp2s0
E: ID_OUI_FROM_DATABASE=Super Micro Computer, Inc.
texts.text:
# udevadm info -e | grep -A 10 ^P.*enp2s0
P: /devices/pci0000:00/0000:00:1c.4/0000:02:00.0/net/enp2s0
E: DEVPATH=/devices/pci0000:00/0000:00:1c.4/0000:02:00.0/net/enp2s0
E: ID_BUS=pci
E: ID_MODEL_FROM_DATABASE=82574L Gigabit Network Connection
E: ID_MODEL_ID=0x10d3
E: ID_NET_DRIVER=e1000e
E: ID_NET_LINK_FILE=/usr/lib/systemd/network/99-default.link
E: ID_NET_NAME=enp2s0
E: ID_NET_NAME_MAC=enx00259025963a
E: ID_NET_NAME_PATH=enp2s0
E: ID_OUI_FROM_DATABASE=Super Micro Computer, Inc.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: And here's all four ports in
texts.text: And here's all four ports in

texts.label: code
texts.orig: lspci
texts.text: lspci

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# for i in `seq 2 5`; do lspci -s 0${i}:; done
02:00.0 Ethernet controller: Intel Corporation 82574L Gigabit Network Connection
03:00.0 Ethernet controller: Intel Corporation 82574L Gigabit Network Connection
04:00.0 Ethernet controller: Intel Corporation 82574L Gigabit Network Connection
05:00.0 Ethernet controller: Intel Corporation 82574L Gigabit Network Connection
texts.text:
# for i in `seq 2 5`; do lspci -s 0${i}:; done
02:00.0 Ethernet controller: Intel Corporation 82574L Gigabit Network Connection
03:00.0 Ethernet controller: Intel Corporation 82574L Gigabit Network Connection
04:00.0 Ethernet controller: Intel Corporation 82574L Gigabit Network Connection
05:00.0 Ethernet controller: Intel Corporation 82574L Gigabit Network Connection

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: These are interesting because they're not all on the same PCI bus. They sit on buses 2-5 in slot 0. There are no function indexes here, so they're named  enp2s0  through  enp5s0 . These aren't true  onboard  cards, so they're named based on their locations.
texts.text: These are interesting because they're not all on the same PCI bus. They sit on buses 2-5 in slot 0. There are no function indexes here, so they're named  enp2s0  through  enp5s0 . These aren't true  onboard  cards, so they're named based on their locations.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Storage server with onboard ethernet
texts.text: Storage server with onboard ethernet

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Here's an example of a server with a true inboard ethernet card:
texts.text: Here's an example of a server with a true inboard ethernet card:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
$ udevadm info -e | grep -A 11 ^P.*eno1
P: /devices/pci0000:00/0000:00:19.0/net/eno1
E: DEVPATH=/devices/pci0000:00/0000:00:19.0/net/eno1
E: ID_BUS=pci
E: ID_MODEL_FROM_DATABASE=Ethernet Connection I217-V
E: ID_MODEL_ID=0x153b
E: ID_NET_DRIVER=e1000e
E: ID_NET_LABEL_ONBOARD=en Onboard LAN
E: ID_NET_LINK_FILE=/usr/lib/systemd/network/99-default.link
E: ID_NET_NAME_MAC=enxe03f49b159c0
E: ID_NET_NAME_ONBOARD=eno1
E: ID_NET_NAME_PATH=enp0s25
E: ID_OUI_FROM_DATABASE=ASUSTek COMPUTER INC.
texts.text:
$ udevadm info -e | grep -A 11 ^P.*eno1
P: /devices/pci0000:00/0000:00:19.0/net/eno1
E: DEVPATH=/devices/pci0000:00/0000:00:19.0/net/eno1
E: ID_BUS=pci

E: ID_MODEL_ID=0x153b
E: ID_NET_DRIVER=e1000e

E: ID_NET_LINK_FILE=/usr/lib/systemd/network/99-default.link
E: ID_NET_NAME_MAC=enxe03f49b159c0
E: ID_NET_NAME_ONBOARD=eno1
E: ID_NET_NAME_PATH=enp0s25
E: ID_OUI_FROM_DATABASE=ASUSTek COMPUTER INC.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: And the
texts.text: And the

texts.label: code
texts.orig: lspci
texts.text: lspci

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: output:
texts.text: output:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
$ lspci -s 00:19.0
00:19.0 Ethernet controller: Intel Corporation Ethernet Connection I217-V (rev 05)
texts.text:
$ lspci -s 00:19.0
00:19.0 Ethernet controller: Intel Corporation Ethernet Connection I217-V (rev 05)

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This card has a new name showing up in udev:
texts.text: This card has a new name showing up in udev:

texts.label: code
texts.orig: ID_NET_NAME_ONBOARD
texts.text: ID_NET_NAME_ONBOARD

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: . The systemd udev code has some special handling for onboard cards because they usually sit on the main bus. The naming can get a bit ugly because that 19 would need to be converted into hex for the name.
texts.text: . The systemd udev code has some special handling for onboard cards because they usually sit on the main bus. The naming can get a bit ugly because that 19 would need to be converted into hex for the name.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: If systemd didn't handle onboard cards differently, this card might be named something ugly like enp0s13 (since 19 in decimal becomes 13 in hex). That's really confusing.
texts.text: If systemd didn't handle onboard cards differently, this card might be named something ugly like enp0s13 (since 19 in decimal becomes 13 in hex). That's really confusing.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Picking the final name
texts.text: Picking the final name

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: As we've seen above, udev makes a big list of names in the udev database. However, there can only be one name in the OS when you try to use the network card.
texts.text: As we've seen above, udev makes a big list of names in the udev database. However, there can only be one name in the OS when you try to use the network card.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Let's wander back into the code. this time we're going to take a look in  src/udev/net/link-config.c  starting at around line 403:
texts.text: Let's wander back into the code. this time we're going to take a look in  src/udev/net/link-config.c  starting at around line 403:

texts.label: code
paragraph
texts.orig: If we look at the overall case statement, you can see that the first match is the one that takes precedence. Working from top to bottom, udev takes the first match of:
texts.text: If we look at the overall case statement, you can see that the first match is the one that takes precedence. Working from top to bottom, udev takes the first match of:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ID_NET_NAME_FROM_DATABASE
texts.text: ID_NET_NAME_FROM_DATABASE

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ID_NET_NAME_ONBOARD
texts.text: ID_NET_NAME_ONBOARD

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ID_NET_NAME_SLOT
texts.text: ID_NET_NAME_SLOT

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ID_NET_NAME_PATH
texts.text: ID_NET_NAME_PATH

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ID_NET_NAME_MAC
texts.text: ID_NET_NAME_MAC

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: If we go back to our OnMetal example way at the top of the post, we can follow the logic. The udev database contained the following:
texts.text: If we go back to our OnMetal example way at the top of the post, we can follow the logic. The udev database contained the following:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
E: ID_NET_NAME_MAC=enxa0369f2cec90
E: ID_NET_NAME_PATH=enp8s0f0
E: ID_NET_NAME_SLOT=ens9f0
texts.text:
E: ID_NET_NAME_MAC=enxa0369f2cec90
E: ID_NET_NAME_PATH=enp8s0f0
E: ID_NET_NAME_SLOT=ens9f0

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The udev daemon would start with
texts.text: The udev daemon would start with

texts.label: code
texts.orig: ID_NET_NAME_FROM_DATABASE
texts.text: ID_NET_NAME_FROM_DATABASE

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: , but that doesn't exist for this card. Next, it would move to
texts.text: , but that doesn't exist for this card. Next, it would move to

texts.label: code
texts.orig: ID_NET_NAME_ONBOARD
texts.text: ID_NET_NAME_ONBOARD

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: , but that's not present. Next comes
texts.text: , but that's not present. Next comes

texts.label: code
texts.orig: ID_NET_NAME_SLOT
texts.text: ID_NET_NAME_SLOT

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: , and we have a match! The
texts.text: , and we have a match! The

texts.label: code
texts.orig: ID_NET_NAME_SLOT
texts.text: ID_NET_NAME_SLOT

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: entry has  ens9f0  and that's the final name for the network device.
texts.text: entry has  ens9f0  and that's the final name for the network device.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This loop also handles some special cases. The first check is to see if someone requested for udev to not use predictable naming. We saw this in the  systemd-networkd bonding post  when the bootloader configuration contained  net.ifnames=0 . If that kernel command line parameter is present, predictable naming logic is skipped.
texts.text: This loop also handles some special cases. The first check is to see if someone requested for udev to not use predictable naming. We saw this in the  systemd-networkd bonding post  when the bootloader configuration contained  net.ifnames=0 . If that kernel command line parameter is present, predictable naming logic is skipped.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Another special case is
texts.text: Another special case is

texts.label: code
texts.orig: ID_NET_NAME_FROM_DATABASE
texts.text: ID_NET_NAME_FROM_DATABASE

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: . Those ports come from udev's internal hardware database. That file only has one item at the moment and it's for a particular Dell iDRAC network interface.
texts.text: . Those ports come from udev's internal hardware database. That file only has one item at the moment and it's for a particular Dell iDRAC network interface.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Perplexed by hex
texts.text: Perplexed by hex

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: If the PCI slot numbers don't seem to line up, be sure to  read my post from last summer . I ran into a peculiar Dell server with a dual port Intel card on PCI bus 42. The interface ended up with a name of  enp66s0f0  and I was stumped.
texts.text: If the PCI slot numbers don't seem to line up, be sure to  read my post from last summer . I ran into a peculiar Dell server with a dual port Intel card on PCI bus 42. The interface ended up with a name of  enp66s0f0  and I was stumped.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The name  enp66s0f0  seems to say that we have a card on PCI bus 66, in slot 0, with multiple function index numbers (for multiple ports). However, systemd does a conversion of PCI slot numbers into hex. That means that decimal 66 becomes 42 in hex.
texts.text: The name  enp66s0f0  seems to say that we have a card on PCI bus 66, in slot 0, with multiple function index numbers (for multiple ports). However, systemd does a conversion of PCI slot numbers into hex. That means that decimal 66 becomes 42 in hex.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Most servers won't be this complicated, but it's key to remember the hex conversion.
texts.text: Most servers won't be this complicated, but it's key to remember the hex conversion.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Feedback
texts.text: Feedback

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Are these systemd-related posts interesting? Let me know. I'm a huge fan of systemd and I enjoy writing about it.
texts.text: Are these systemd-related posts interesting? Let me know. I'm a huge fan of systemd and I enjoy writing about it.
